Key Arguments: The Bill gives excessive power to the government to censor content.
The exclusion of government-authorised content is hypocritical.
The Bill is inconsistent with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights regarding freedom of expression.
The definition of 'harm' is too broad and could suppress necessary debate.
Penalties for non-compliance are excessive and could hinder free speech.
The public should be allowed to discern truth from falsehood through open debate.
Notable Quotes: This Bill does not strike an appropriate balance between freedom of expression and online safety.
The government is not the final authority on what is true and should not be the final authority (through social media companies) on what is permissible online.
